story:
Hi Guys!

I had a lovely little Facebook advertisement pop up from Macmillan about the #AlphaPet challenge. 

This consists of taking a photo of your pet each day, with a theme or object starting from the beginning of the alphabet! 

As you may already know, I have two dogs, a 5 year old Siberian Husky called Zeus, a 5 month old Golden Retriever called Huckleberry, and a tiny black and white cat called Duncan. I constantly hammer my Facebook page in with pictures of these buddies, so I thought why not do what I love to do, but hopefully raise some money for a good cause to accompany this! 

I'll be starting this on the 5th November with the letter A (obviously!), not too sure where I'll get a xylophone or an x-ray from when I hit that date, so wish me luck with that one! 

Any donation would be greatly appreciated, and if you can't donate, that is no problem at all! Please just enjoy the several photos of my goofy pets! 

To find out any more information about Macmillan Cancer Support, please visit: https://www.macmillan.org.uk/

Lots of Love

Faye xox

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

For those of you who know me, (and for those that don’t), Cancer has had a significant effect on me and my family this year - on more than one occasion, and in a range of severities. During what has already been the most challenging of times, Cancer has impacted my year more profoundly than the other big C we’ve come to know - Covid. 

There have been many difficulties and challenges faced this year with Covid, but for people living with Cancer, and for their families trying to support from afar, the pandemic has left devastation in its wake. 

With a new lockdown now in effect, I wanted to use this time to help raise as much money as possible, to support families who find themselves in a similar situation to myself earlier this year. 

Therefore, I plan to run a minimum of 5KM every day during the lockdown period. A current total of 30 days (longer if Boris extends the lockdown) beginning on Thursday 4th November. 

You can follow my journey through my Instagram account @rg_crawley. 

Or 

Strava account - https://www.strava.com/athletes/crawley_ryan 

Please donate to help me reach my £1000 goal and improve the lives of individuals and families affected by Cancer and the impossible situation COVID-19 has presents.

story:
This year alone I have lost a dog, a friend and someone I considered to be a brother to cancer. I watched as the death of my childhood dog devastated my family, how the death of my friend left everyone she knew grieving her loss and finally how the death of a brother broke my brothers and his family. As you may imagine I didn't come out of these tragedies unscathed I came out beaten, bruised and broken. I have only recently realised that cancer isn't a disease that affects one person cancer incubates in one person and when that person dies the cancer spreads and brings misery to all that were close.

With the help of donations no matter how big or small we can make a difference in the fight against cancer, if we raise enough money for even one extra test to be done that means we are closer to a cure than we were the day before and to me that's more than worth the price.

So help me raise funds and together we can stand up and say "Fuck Cancer"

eventName: South Gwynedd 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas
story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection 

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs 
this Christmas! 

During December the four-legged volunteers of the  South Gwynedd Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.  

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this 
festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!  

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.  

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, 
social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future. 

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too. 

Thank you and Merry Christmas

	Donate £12 and share our posts across social media nominating a friend, family member or colleague to  get involved

story:
For the past four years, our beloved Steve was an active volunteer as a puppy walker for Guide Dogs for the blind.

It is a charity close to our hearts, Steve passed away suddenly on the 18th October 2020 which has left a hole in the lives of our family and many people that knew him.

I’ve lost my rock and life partner, he was always by my side and was a guide.

story:

I wanted to do something to help the research, because without it those recoveries may not have been possible.

If you want to donate to this page then you are very welcome, as any help would be much appreciated. I've set a realistic target of £100, why, because my dad loved cricket and a milestone for any batsman is to get a century. I'm also aware that in these difficult times finances can be a little bit tight for anyone wanting to donate. Any funds raised that exceeds the target would be a bonus as it all helps with the research into diagnosis, treatment and prevention.

My son, Peter, works for Marie Curie Charity. Charities have suffered as well during the COVID-19 pandemic so I’ve decided to do something to help by supporting the Marie Curie 12 Days of Christmas Challenge.

Since the beginning of the first lockdown I’ve kept a record (via the app Strava) of my cycling. The intention was to do 1000 kilometres by the end of the year and gain sponsorship as long as it looks as though I could get near the target. So far I’ve done over 900 km, so now the fundraising begins.  I’m no cyclist but I’ve been fortunate that the weather has been clement (in the first lockdown particularly) and that where we live is relatively flat.

My aim is to raise £1000 for Marie Curie, by cycling the remaining kilometres by 12th December in line with the  First 12 Days of December Marie Curie Christmas Challenge guidelines. 

Any amount of financial support will help Marie Curie do their wonderful work. They have not been able to fundraise in their normal ways because of national COVID restrictions. For example, the Daffodil Appeal, which we normally support, would have been an enormous fundraiser but was curtailed by lockdown earlier this year.

When (sic) I’ve done the 1000 kilometres I’ll post  here to show the distance has been achieved  - but you don’t have to wait until then - you’re welcome to donate anytime. Thank you in advance.

story:
What am I doing


In August 2021, I will be setting off on a new adventure, to climb the mighty Mount Kilimanjaro. Mount Kilimanjaro is the largest mountain in Africa and the largest free standing mountain in the world! This trip will take place over 9 days altogether and include 6 days of trekking (68km of walking).  I will be doing this with other university students via a company called ‘Choose a Challenge’, whilst supporting the brilliant Marie Curie charity. 


Why am I doing this


From a young age my brother and I had been exposed to trekking and mountain climbing, and now it has become a hobby. The two people who introduced us to this were my Uncle and my dad. My dad, Jayesh Chauhan was born in Nairobi, Kenya, which is next door to the mountain. His father, my grandfather, climbed Mount Kilimanjaro in his early 20’s.  This amazing effort by my grandfather was not lost on my dad and over the years the goal of following in his father's footsteps became a dream. My Uncle Rob and dad made plans and placed it on their ‘to do’ list.

Before they could turn the dream into a reality and at the age of only 56 my dad was diagnosed with a brain tumour.  Glioblastoma is a stage 4 cancer and is extremely aggressive. They are the most common primary brain tumour in adults. The life expectancy after being diagnosed is short.

In the blink of an eye life would never be the same again. As a family we changed our way of living to suit what was best for dad’s needs. The effects of a Glioblastoma on someone vary, and can only be slowed but not stopped. Over a year and a half we slowly witnessed the changes in dads actions and behavior, as the cancer began eating away at his brain. 

Dad fought back and fought hard refusing to give in.  However despite his, ours and the doctors best efforts, dad's condition deteriorated.  It was subtle changes to start with like partial loss of vision and concentration with mild depression. As time moved on things worsened, his sight and speech slowly disappeared. Towards the last few months he had no control over his body. His legs gave way and he was incapable of communicating with us properly. He struggled to do anything independently and needed full time care - which my Mum, brother and I, with the help of family and friends provided.

Despite his condition, there were three things my dad never stopped saying until his last few days when he could no longer speak. The first one being that he loved us, the second, thanking everyone around him and the third, telling himself ‘C’mon Jayesh you can do this, c’mon Jayesh…’ My dad was a true gentleman until the end. My dad was our Hero. 

I was meant to start Aberdeen University in September 2019.  However due to dad's worsening condition and the distances involved, I decided to defer my placement. This meant I could provide support for my family to help look after dad and be by his side the whole way.

Unfortunately the fight for dad was short lived.  On Sunday 13th October 2019 just a little before 2pm, dad fell asleep in my mums arms with my brother, myself and his family by his side.

Dad had so many unfulfilled dreams, probably as we all do when our time is up.  But this dream, this goal, this mountain, is one dream that is very personal to us as a family. I know my dad will be behind me all the way and I fully intend to stand on the summit of the mountain and feel proud of my achievement in memory of my dad.


Why Support me


My family and I saw first hand how important end of life care is and what a difference it can make to vulnerable families like us.  Marie Curie cares for more than 140,000 terminally ill people in the UK a year. It is a charity which relies on donations, two thirds of which come from donations and supporters and the rest from the NHS.  Although my dad was not at a Marie Curie Hospice, but at The Princess Alice Hospice in Surrey, we saw how essential their work is and what a difference it can make to families who are in desperate need of help and support at this vital time. Without the help of thousands of supporters, hospices and charities like Princess Alice and Marie Curie would not exist and these services are vital for those in need at the most crucial time in their lives.  Now more than ever, in these unprecedented times, these charities need our help. So please, please support me in supporting them! 

My family and friends will join me in fundraising events throughout the year...watch this space and feel free to join us where you can!!

story:
Rebecca’s story..

On 28th August this year myself and my family spent the day on Freshwater West beach. Just before we left for the day I decided I would like a little swim so headed into the water jumping over the waves then swimming into the waves with the water just waist height. Suddenly I felt myself being swept further and further away from the shore! Thinking that surely if I swim with the waves I will be brought back to the shore? Actually it's I was caught in a rip tide and the shore and the people on it kept getting smaller and smaller. This all happened within seconds and was so so frightening. I then seriously panicked as this was getting worse so I started waving and screaming for help in between being plunged under by huge unrelenting waves. I totally thought my time was up when there appeared my angel...an RNLI lifeguard in his board to rescue me!! Thank you thank you RNLI

Please help me to raise money for this often forgotten charity. Donate if you’re glad I’m still alive !!!! If I’m not your cup of tea then don’t 🤪 But on a serious note if you can please help raise some money for these superstars!! 

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.

story:
Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF, Doctors Without Borders) is an international humanitarian aid organisation. MSF’s core values are independent, neutral and impartial; aid workers go wherever they are needed the most.

It takes an extreme amount of organisation to mobilise, transport and create an appropriate response to whatever disaster needs assistance - MSF works in remote locations around the globe as well as rapid relief efforts in countries such as Yemen and Rohingya. In addition to emergency work, MSF builds long-term connections with governments to provide education and deliver prevention campaigns. Notably, MSF’s work is dependent on the likes of logisticians, project coordinators, and water & sanitation specialists on top of healthcare professionals.

At Imperial Friends of MSF, we are wholeheartedly committed to increasing the awareness of MSF so that they can continue their compassionate work. We are grateful to collaborate with Imperial College Consultancy Society and hope that you will support MSF's work!

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

It sounds normal and it should be.
